headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Mr. Brian Angeli, Vice President, Investor Relations for FMC Corporation. Mr. Angeli,
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Mr. Brian Angeli, Vice President, Investor Relations for FMC Corporation. Mr. Angeli, you may begin.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning everyone. Welcome to FMC Corporation's first quarter 2016 earnings call. Joining me today is Pierre Brondeau, President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Paul Graves, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Office
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning everyone. Welcome to FMC Corporation's first quarter 2016 earnings call. Joining me today is Pierre Brondeau, President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Paul Graves, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Pierre will begin the call with a review of FMC's first quarter performance and discuss the outlook for Q2 and the full year 2016. Paul will provide an overview of select financial results. 
The slide presentation that accompanies our results along with our earnings release and 2016 outlook statement are currently available on our website. The prepared remarks from today's discussion will be made available at the conclusion of the call. 
Following the prepared remarks, we will be joined by Mark Douglas, President, FMC Agricultural Solutions; Eric Norris, President FMC Health and Nutrition; and Tom Schneberger, Vice President and Global Business Director, FMC Lithium, to address your questions. 
Before I turn the call over to Pierre, let me remind you that today's discussion will include forward-looking statements that are subject to various risks and uncertainties concerning specific factors including, but not limited to, those factors identified in our release and in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Information presented represents our best judgment based on today's information. Actual results may vary based on these risks and uncertainties. 
Today's discussion will focus on adjusted earnings for all income statement and EPS references and pro forma revenue and segment earnings for FMC Agricultural Solutions. A reconciliation and definition of these terms as well as other non-GAAP financial terms, to which we may refer during today's conference call, are provided on our website. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Pierre

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. 2016 marks the beginning of a new era for FMC. Today, FMC is a more focused and streamlined company. Our businesses operate in attractive end markets namely Agriculture, Nutrition, Pharmaceuticals and Lithium.
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. 2016 marks the beginning of a new era for FMC. Today, FMC is a more focused and streamlined company. Our businesses operate in attractive end markets namely Agriculture, Nutrition, Pharmaceuticals and Lithium. The actions we have taken over the past 18 months have aligned our operation with regional market demand and positioned each of our businesses to better capitalize on market opportunities. With our transformation complete, we are now solely focused on the execution of our strategy to drive pro forma in 2016 and beyond.
In Agricultural Solutions, we continue to see the benefits of the Cheminova acquisition. Prior to the acquisition, Ag Solutions was very much an American business. In 2014, more than 3 quarters of its revenues were generated in North and South America. Cheminova significantly increased the size of Ag Solutions operations in Europe and Asia, bringing greater scale and market access to Ag Solutions operations across our region. The increased global sale of operations, combined with actions we have taken in North and South America, will bring greater original bounds to Ag Solutions, aligning our operations with the global crop protection chemical market and limit Ag Solutions' reliance on any one region or market to drive performance.
For example, in 2014 almost 40% of Ag Solutions' revenue was generated in Brazil alone. In 2016, we expect Brazil to account for less than 20% of segment revenue and only 15% of total company revenue. 
Across the global ag market, conditions in the Americas remain the most challenging. With greater scale and regional balance, FMC is able to better manage our business in the Americas to address market conditions. Specifically, we researched an operation in Brazil to align the size of our business with market conditions and rationalize our product offering to increase our focus on higher margin, proprietary technology platforms and differentiated products. While these actions reduce our revenues in Brazil, they improved the quality of our operations and enhanced the potential to deliver higher earnings and return on capital.
In North America, we are supporting customer inventory draw downs to more closely match our sales with underlying grow our demand, an important step to further strengthen FMC's position from which to protect price and terms. Cheminova also expanded our product portfolio and technology pipeline and provided the opportunity to realize meaningful cost savings. We are already seeing the benefits of our expanded product portfolio in North America and Europe and the integration of Cheminova is progressing well. We remain on track to deliver the full run rate cost savings of $140 million to $160 million by the middle of 2017.
In Health and Nutrition, global demand for FMC's naturally derived ingredients product lines continue to be robust and we remain focused on maintaining the business' high margins through the implementation of manufacturing excellence program, process technology improvements and product differentiation.
In Lithium, we are seeing the benefits of our strategy to focus and grow FMC's business in the technology-driven specialty end market where demand continues to climb and pricing trends across FMC's portfolio remain favorable. I will discuss the performance of each of our businesses shortly and provide an update on our outlook for Q2 and the full year.
First, I will start with a brief review of FMC's consolidated reported results on Slide 2. FMC reported first quarter revenue of approximately $799 million. Adjusted EPS of $0.58 [ph] for the quarter was flat compared to the first quarter of 2015 but was towards the top end of our organic range as a solid performance in Ag Solutions and a very strong quarter for Lithium drove the results.
Turning now to Ag Solutions on Slide 3. Ag Solutions reported revenue of $546 million, a decline of 22% compared to pro forma results for the first quarter of 2015 has lower sales volume in North America and Brazil due to high channel inventories, planned product rationalization and currency headwinds more than offset the impact of price increases, revenue synergies and new product introductions in the quarter.
As I mentioned previously, we are focused on executing our strategy to drive improved performance. This includes completing the process of rationalizing the Ag Solutions product portfolio that began in 2014. The actions we took to eliminate certain products from our portfolio reduced revenue by approximately $30 million or 4% compared to pro forma revenue for Q1 2015.
However, as discussed in prior quarters, this product rationalization has a limited impact on segment earnings. We also remain focused on pricing discipline. At the operating earnings level, price increases implemented in Brazil more than offset the year-over-year impact of the weaker real. However, the broad-based strength of the U.S. dollar resulted in headwinds in Europe and Asia that are only partially offset by price increases.
Despite challenging market conditions, the Ag Solution business delivered segment earnings of $82 million, ahead of the midpoint of organic and maintain operating margins year-over-year on a pro forma basis. 
I will make a few additional comments regarding regional market conditions and Ag Solutions' performance now on Slide 4. Overall market conditions and our performance in the quarter were very much as expected. In North America, as we discussed on our Q4 earnings call back in February, the deterioration in farm incomes over the past year, combined with elevated channel inventory levels led distributors and growers to delay purchases of agricultural foods, including crop protection chemicals. We determined it was critical to maintain price and payment terms in North America this season. And as part of our strategy to achieve these, we believe it was important to allow the level of FMC product inventory in the sales channel to reduce. Our decision to allow FMC product inventory in the sales channel to be drawn down was the main factor behind the 35% decline in revenue in North America in the quarter compared to pro forma revenue for the first quarter 2015.
However, we anticipate full year revenue performance for Ag Solutions in North America will be largely in line with the broader North America crop protection market as the action we are taking today will facilitate increased sales in the second half of the year. In fact, the dollar we are seeing give us increased confidence that our approach to managing Ag Solutions business in North America will help protect price and terms in 2016.
Despite lower sales into the channel, FMC continues to gain market share when looking at growers' use of products. Based on independent data, application of FMC products or products on the ground rose 7% in the quarter compared to Q1 2015. In particular, we continue to see strength in FMC's authority brand pre-emergent herbicides, which address a growing number of soybean acres which exhibit glyphosate resistance. As a result, we are confident the reduction in revenue in Q1 is due more to a decision as went-to-sell than it is in any change in underlying demand for FMC products. And it is this strong good demand for FMC's portfolio of technical products which will ultimately provide the support of pricing and terms that we are focused on.
In addition, we continue to see demand by growers for new innovative and differentiated products that provide high-value end use. Recent product launches in FMC and the introduction of our expanded fungicide product offering as a result of the Cheminova acquisition received strong support from growers and distributors in the quarter. We also saw strong acceptance of our new biological and seed [ph] product combinations, including brand such as capturing VGR and [indiscernible]. 
In Latin America, revenue declined approximately 25% compared to the first quarter of 2015. Lower demand and planned product rationalizations in Brazil more than offset increased sales volume in the rest of Latin America.
Excluding this portfolio rationalization, sales in Latin America declined approximately 15% in line with the overall market. Market conditions in Brazil were a little changed from the fourth quarter of 2015. Channel inventory levels have improved but remain elevated, most notably in soybean insecticide in the northern states. However, we are seeing an increase in demand in the north for insecticide, such as FMC's Talisman [ph] to address pressure in soybean. 
In Southern Brazil, market conditions are improved, especially in sugarcane and certain niche crops such as coffee and [indiscernible]
We continue to remain disciplined on pricing in Brazil. As we have explained previously, greater stability in the Brazilian real to U.S. dollar exchange rate supports price increase to offset FX headwinds. Paul will comment further on the impact of foreign currencies later in the call. 
Outside of Brazil, we continue to see increasing demand for pre-emergent herbicides in Argentina and products for niche crops in Colombia and Mexico. In Argentina, we see improved conditions with far fewer restrictions on imports and with the leasing of export taxes for key crops. 
In Europe, sales declined approximately 11% as foreign exchange headwinds and lower market volume more than offset commercial synergies from the Cheminova transaction and new product launches in the quarter. A cold snap at the end of the winter impacted the season in certain Western European markets, and we have seen some tightening of demand by growers in an attempt to control costs in the face of persistently below grain prices. Strong demand in Central and Eastern Europe and FMC's transition to Cheminova's direct market access model in Europe partially offset the pullback in market activity in the quarter.
Sales volumes across Europe increased for FMC's legal portfolio, including herbicides and insecticides for [indiscernible]. With the benefits of a broader combined portfolio, we believe the business is well-positioned to address market demand in key crops, including [indiscernible] and all [indiscernible].
Profitability in the region improved meaningfully year-over-year as the move to direct market access, combined with other cost savings from the Cheminova integration, increased operating margins in Europe by about 200 basis points. 
In Asia, we saw increased demand in China and Australia. However, the stronger U.S. dollar combined with planned product rationalization and poor weather in India and Southeast Asia resulted in a 13% decline in pro forma revenue compared to the prior year quarter. Excluding the impact of currency and planned product rationalization, revenue decreased about 3% driven largely by lower sales volume in India.
Globally, we expect the challenging market conditions to persist for the remainder of the year. As previously stated, we believe the global crop protection chemicals market will decline by a mid- to high-single-digit percentage in 2016 on a U.S. dollar basis driven largely by market conditions in North America and Brazil.
We remain highly focused on decreasing FMC product inventory levels in the channel, holding on price in turn and increasing collections of accounts receivable. 
Our full year guidance for Ag Solutions remains unchanged. We continue to forecast full year revenue of between $2.3 billion and $2.5 billion and full year segment earnings in the range of $380 million to $420 million. In the second quarter, we expect to deliver segment earnings in the range of $90 million to $110 million, along with sequential margin improvement as we move toward the main selling season in North America and Europe. 
Turning next to Health and Nutrition on Slide 5. First quarter performance for Health and Nutrition was broadly in line with expectations. The business reported revenue of $192 million and segment earnings of $47 million. First quarter 2016 revenue declined approximately $19 million compared to the first quarter of last year. 
As discussed on our fourth quarter earnings call, last year's first quarter revenue included certain omega-3 sales which were not expected to occur in 2016. These sales relate principally to pharmaceutical API products and account for a decline in the revenue compared to the prior year period.
Excluding these sales volume and impact of currency, revenue was essentially flat compared to last year. 
Global demand for FMC's Health excipient products continues to grow, resulting in higher sales volume of minor and [indiscernible] products in the quarter. However, lower sales in functional health due to timing and a more competitive omega-3 pricing environment broadly offset the increase in health excipient revenue. 
For the first quarter 2016, Health and Nutrition reported segment earnings of $47 million while lower operating costs resulted in an increase in segment earnings margin to 24.6%. Looking forward, we continue to expect full year revenue in the range of $775 million and $825 million, and segment earnings of between $198 million and $208 million, driven principally by continued growth and demand for MCC-based health excipients and nutritional ingredients in North America and Asia and lower operating cost from ongoing manufacturing excellence program and process technology improvement. 
We expect Health and Nutrition second quarter segment earnings of between $49 million and $53 million with a sequential improvement in segment earnings margin in the quarter.
Turning to Lithium on Slide 6. Lithium delivered an outstanding quarter. Compared to the first quarter of 2015, revenue increased 8% to $60 [ph] million and segment earnings almost threefold to $14.9 million. Segment's operating margin climbed from under 10% last year in Q1 to almost 25% this quarter. These results reflect the impact of our strategy to focus on the downstream specialty markets. 
As a result of our advantaged process technology and ability to manage sales mix, FMC is uniquely positioned to serve the higher growth and higher-value specialty segments while maintaining the flexibility to take advantage of favorable market conditions in lithium carbonate and chloride.
Demand trends across specialty end markets remain strong. Demand for lithium hydroxide for energy storage and electric vehicle, or EV applications, continues to grow at double-digit rates. Our success in increasing throughput from our existing hydroxide asset allow FMC to deliver higher sales volume in the quarter. In addition, we managed our production mix in order to optimize our sales of butyllithium and high-purity lithium minerals. 
Favorable market conditions supported price increases across the FMC portfolio. We continue to realize price increases for lithium hydroxide while our approach to the carbonate and chloride markets is allowing us to achieve meaningful price increases from the limited sales volume. The extent to which carbonate and chloride prices remain elevated will depend on how quickly new supply comes online. We expect market supply of all product to remain tight in the near to midterm.
Lower operating cost coupled with higher specialty sales volume and price increases resulted in significant increases in segment earnings and margins in the quarter. Manufacturing efficiencies from ongoing process improvement initiatives and lower cost associated with the natural gas pipeline installed in 2015 reduced operating costs by more than $5 million year-over-year, helping to drive the increased operating margin in the quarter. 
We expect the second quarter to be another strong period for the Lithium business. We continue to shift our sales mix to grow our specialty product line, serving markets such as [indiscernible] and polymers while capitalizing on favorable market conditions in lithium carbonate. However, we expect to have slightly lower available carbonate volumes in Q2 compared to Q1, as a result of lower seasonal production in Argentina.
Consequently, we expect quarter segment earnings to be in the range of $10 million to $14 million and segment earnings margin in the range of 19% to 20%. Based on Lithium performance to date and our expectation for the remainder of 2016, we are raising our full year outlook for the Lithium business. We now expect full year revenue to be between $245 million and $265 [ph] million and segment earnings to be in the range of $43 million to $53 million, up $10 million from the prior range. 
Moving next to our outlook for the second quarter and full year 2016 on Slide 7. I previously commented on the outlook for each business for both Q2 and the full year. As I mentioned, we are maintaining segment earnings guidance for the full year for both Ag Solutions and Health and Nutrition. Segment earnings guidance for the second quarter reflect normal earnings level for these businesses based on our expectation for 2016. We are increasing the full year segment earnings guidance for Lithium as stated earlier. 
On a consolidated basis, we are increasing full year 2016 adjusted earnings per share by $0.05 versus previous guidance to a range of $2.55 to $2.85, and we expect second quarter 2016 adjusted earnings to be between $0.62 and $0.72 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Paul to discuss select financial results, including taxes, foreign exchange and cash flow.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Pierre. As usual, I'll start with the income statement and specifically the tax rate. Our adjusted effective tax rate fell from 27.5% in the first quarter 2015 to 26% in Q1 '16. Part of this was the continued change in the mix of our
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Pierre. As usual, I'll start with the income statement and specifically the tax rate. Our adjusted effective tax rate fell from 27.5% in the first quarter 2015 to 26% in Q1 '16. Part of this was the continued change in the mix of our earnings away from the U.S. and Brazil and towards Europe and Asia where rates are typically lowered. We continue to take steps to increase our tax efficiency and expect that the full year rate will come in somewhere in the 24% to 26% range. 
A theme in our earnings in recent quarters has been the impact of foreign currency movements, and the movement in the Brazilian real has been a particular area of focus. In the first quarter, the average rate of the reais the dollar was 3.9 [ph], significantly weaker than 2.87 [ph] average the same quarter a year ago. However, the total impact on our earnings was far less than we have seen in prior quarters for 2 main reasons. First, as you know, Q1 is not a large selling quarter for us in Brazil, reducing the impact of currency movement. Also, since we have not seen particularly volatile movements in the currency, our price list has been able to reflect the new currency levels for the entire quarter. As a result, the $13 million headwinds created by the weaker reais year-on-year was completely offset by price increases. In fact, the positive impact of the weaker real on our cost base and of the change in the real was actually enough positive driving constraint in Q1. 
Looking to the rest of the work, although a number of Asian currencies collectively reduced earnings, the only major currency we faced headwind in the quarter was the euro, which devalued by 2% versus the same period last year. The net hit for operating earnings from currency movements in the quarter was approximately $14 [ph] million. 
A second common theme of our earnings has also been the challenges of operating in Argentina, including areas such as import licenses restrictions, negative impacts of export duties and the headwind created by the disconnect between cost inflation and the pace of devaluation of peso against the dollar. Since the election of [indiscernible] as President, we have seen a rapid shift in all of these areas, to the benefits of our operations in Ag Solutions and especially Lithium. The devaluation of the peso had a relatively limited impact in our earnings in the quarter in Lithium since the lower cost of operations takes 1 to 2 quarters to work its way out of inventory and into the income statement. And our earnings guidance for 2016 reflect this lower cost of operations. We remain cautiously optimistic that the business environment in Argentina will remain positive and will continue to create opportunities for FMC. 
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow on Slide 8. Q1 is historically the period in which we consumed the most cash given the seasonal nature of our Ag business. However, discipline around spending, the increased focus last year on sales terms, and of course the ongoing collection measures globally resulted in an improvement of operating cash flow of over $100 million compared to the same quarter last year. Cash flow was helped by higher EBITDA and a better performance around working capital, most notably from collection of receivables. This improvement was seen in all regions. 
With certain cash outflows, particularly capital spending and pension expenses also lower than last year, we were able to hold net debt flat during the quarter. As noted in our filing of March 28, we elected to amend the debt covenants for our term loan and revolver, defering the timing of step downs of our leverage ratios such that we retained the covenant limit of 4.5x for Q1. Our actual leverage ratio under the covenant calculation was 4.0x given the half turn of headwind that we considered to be prudent. 
Looking to the rest of the year, adjusted cash from operations is forecasted in the range of $450 million to $550 million, an improvement over last year of over a third at the midpoint of the range. This is driven by improvements in both EBITDA and working capital performance. Capital expenditure will remain broadly flat to 2015 in the $120 million to $140 million range.
And with that, I will turn the call back to Pierre.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. To conclude, we continue to expect the challenging market in Ag Solutions, but we are managing the business to increase visibility and to protect both price and terms. As a result, we continue to expect full year earnings to be in line wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. To conclude, we continue to expect the challenging market in Ag Solutions, but we are managing the business to increase visibility and to protect both price and terms. As a result, we continue to expect full year earnings to be in line with prior guidance. 
The Health and Nutrition is performing largely in line with expectations and Lithium is well ahead over initial forecast. The portfolio transformation is done. We are now in execution mode, targeting year-over-year earnings growth for each of our 3 businesses. 
Thank you your attention. And I will now turn the call back to the operator for questions.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Christopher Parkinson from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Christopher Parkinson from Crdit Suisse.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in your presentation that Central and Eastern Europe were showing solid demands. But can you comment on the pricing landscape given the FX headwinds there as well, and whether or not you're going to offset that? And then also on the demand f
componenttext: You mentioned in your presentation that Central and Eastern Europe were showing solid demands. But can you comment on the pricing landscape given the FX headwinds there as well, and whether or not you're going to offset that? And then also on the demand front, do you believe the growth is simply driven by the market or do you believe there is any benefit from adding the FMC portfolio to the legacy Cheminova One in the region?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the Central and Eastern Europe, the pricing is pretty stable and it's not a very, very large market. Interesting for us because there is a strong possibility to increase volume. But pricing is quite stable. And I think, definitely, the growth i
componenttext: I think on the Central and Eastern Europe, the pricing is pretty stable and it's not a very, very large market. Interesting for us because there is a strong possibility to increase volume. But pricing is quite stable. And I think, definitely, the growth is one of the place where FMC had no structure in Central and Eastern Europe, where it was an area of focus for Cheminova. So definitely, a place where using the infrastructure and commercial organization from Cheminova and bringing in the product portfolio for FMC is going to create some significant opportunities for us.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And just kind of a tangent question to that one. Given the progression of cost savings, with Cheminova clearly going well, can you just comment on the other geographies as far as intermediate to long-term and revenue synergies, inclusive of the U
componenttext: Perfect. And just kind of a tangent question to that one. Given the progression of cost savings, with Cheminova clearly going well, can you just comment on the other geographies as far as intermediate to long-term and revenue synergies, inclusive of the U.S. and then also in Latin America with Argentina in particular?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Mark. We've talked about North America in the past. In the U.S., we're seeing very good synergies with the fungicide portfolio from Cheminova going through our distribution network. In Latin America, obviously brazil in the South, we're see
componenttext: Chris, this is Mark. We've talked about North America in the past. In the U.S., we're seeing very good synergies with the fungicide portfolio from Cheminova going through our distribution network. In Latin America, obviously brazil in the South, we're seeing increased sales through co-ops where we've made decisions which co-ops and which distribution will go through. Argentina certainly very beneficial for us. Obviously we have a bigger footprint there now. We have the right products for the soy market, so we're expecting to see growth in Argentina. And then in other parts of Latin America, I would say obviously Mexico, Colombia are 2 countries that we're focused on and we're seeing very good synergies in Colombia on these crops.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think when we did the last earnings call as well as multiple discussions we all had, we've been talking about this year getting to $100 million -- $50 million to $100 million run rate in between the synergies and the new products and very much on track
componenttext: I think when we did the last earnings call as well as multiple discussions we all had, we've been talking about this year getting to $100 million -- $50 million to $100 million run rate in between the synergies and the new products and very much on track with that. So it is a place. I think, the opportunities created by Cheminova from a cost saving and the revenue synergies are very much in line with what we're expecting.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pierre, when you were talking about the ag business, you were talking about some positives with respect to the glyphosate resistance in terms of providing a boost. I was wondering if there was a way for you to kind of quantify it? And in terms of where yo
componenttext: Pierre, when you were talking about the ag business, you were talking about some positives with respect to the glyphosate resistance in terms of providing a boost. I was wondering if there was a way for you to kind of quantify it? And in terms of where you see that over the next 18 months or so? And then what sort of concerns may you have about some new technologies that Monsanto and others are rolling out in that area?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, it's Mark. When you look at glyphosate resistance, we are really talking about the U.S., Argentina as the 2 big markets. I think you know that through our authority brands based upon sulfentrazone, we've had great success in the pre-emergent area i
componenttext: Frank, it's Mark. When you look at glyphosate resistance, we are really talking about the U.S., Argentina as the 2 big markets. I think you know that through our authority brands based upon sulfentrazone, we've had great success in the pre-emergent area in both of those countries. I expect that to continue. There will be some headwinds with new technologies coming in. But I think to offset that, we still see more ways to get in resistance in glyphosate and more acres and increasing especially in Argentina. It wouldn't surprise me if we don't start to see that in the next few years start to develop in Brazil as well and we're already positioning our brands in Brazil on soy for that area.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And as you think about some of the combinations coming -- some of the major combinations in the ag chemical world coming over the next 12 months or less, how do you see yourselves perhaps participating and picking up some pieces
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And as you think about some of the combinations coming -- some of the major combinations in the ag chemical world coming over the next 12 months or less, how do you see yourselves perhaps participating and picking up some pieces there? What's the interest level? Can you talk about your participation in the industry consolidation here?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Frank, as you know, we made a move which was in line with what was our strategic intent by acquiring Cheminova. We have now a stable situation from a structural standpoint in Ag. We're finishing up on the integration. What we intend to do at this st
componenttext: Well, Frank, as you know, we made a move which was in line with what was our strategic intent by acquiring Cheminova. We have now a stable situation from a structural standpoint in Ag. We're finishing up on the integration. What we intend to do at this stage is watch what is happening specifically in places when 2 ag companies are coming together. So every time there will be consolidation of ag companies, if at any point during this process, there is -- because of [indiscernible] reasons, products which are made available, that is something we are very good in doing, which is taking a product and commercializing that with our own sales organization. So we're going to be opportunistic. But it's certainly something we will be able to afford to do and we'd be very interested in doing. Beyond that, do not expect us making any major move in acquiring any type of company. It will be an acquisition of technology and products.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Daniel Jester with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Daniel Jester with Citigroup.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a couple of questions on Lithium. Price mix was a 4% benefit in the quarter. But by some kind of spot measures, looking at prices were much higher. So can you just kind of elaborate as how we should be thinking about pricing, kind of commodity and y
componenttext: Maybe a couple of questions on Lithium. Price mix was a 4% benefit in the quarter. But by some kind of spot measures, looking at prices were much higher. So can you just kind of elaborate as how we should be thinking about pricing, kind of commodity and your spot sales versus the contract market as we continue throughout the year?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you think about our Lithium business, look at strategic price increase in place where we are technologically advantaged in grain markets where we have significant contract, which we revenue every year, like in lithium hydroxide. And then think abo
componenttext: Yes. If you think about our Lithium business, look at strategic price increase in place where we are technologically advantaged in grain markets where we have significant contract, which we revenue every year, like in lithium hydroxide. And then think about on the chloride and carbonate side for what is not used for internal purposes or sold in the contract, we are using the spot market to do one-off price increase. We believe that situation is going to carry on for the next few quarters. I think the market will remain tight, which will allow us to use the spot market in the more community businesses like chloride and carbonate to increase price on a spot basis. And where we are with opportunities, where people need our technology or products, we would be increasing price on contract and contract are being renewed. It is a situation which we see fairly, fairly stable for the future. If you look at our increase in guidance for the Lithium business, most of it is -- of the over performance will be due to pricing.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just sticking with Lithium, you commented that you think the outlook is going to be tight in the near to medium term. Can you just flesh out a little bit about what's your expectations are for supply additions over the coming years?
componenttext: Okay. And then just sticking with Lithium, you commented that you think the outlook is going to be tight in the near to medium term. Can you just flesh out a little bit about what's your expectations are for supply additions over the coming years?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I cannot comment too much beyond what all of you know on the lithium carbonate side because that's the decision of the people who have announced capacity increase. So I'm sure [indiscernible] when they talk on their earnings will be able to tell mor
componenttext: Well, I cannot comment too much beyond what all of you know on the lithium carbonate side because that's the decision of the people who have announced capacity increase. So I'm sure [indiscernible] when they talk on their earnings will be able to tell more about the timing. But we believe [indiscernible] will be [indiscernible] and we believe also some Chinese or Asian company will be bringing carbonate capacity in the next couple of years. We, ourselves, are focused more on the downstream and we will bring, in time, and we'll bring more detail in the weeks to come, but we'll be focusing more on increasing lithium hydroxide capacity as needed.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Mike Harrison of Seaport Global.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Mike Harrison of Seaport Global.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pierre, if we could just continue on the Lithium front. I was, I guess I was just surprised to see that you put up $15 [ph] million a quarter in Lithium and your guidance was only calling for $43 million to $53 million for the full year. What's going to c
componenttext: Pierre, if we could just continue on the Lithium front. I was, I guess I was just surprised to see that you put up $15 [ph] million a quarter in Lithium and your guidance was only calling for $43 million to $53 million for the full year. What's going to change during the remainder of the year that would suggest that earnings could be lower than the Q1 level as we get through the rest of the year?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Paul to comment with me. But as we said on the script, remember there are seasons in terms of manufacturing in Lithium and we are getting into a period where, which is the winter part of the season. And we're going to have more rain and more snow
componenttext: I'll ask Paul to comment with me. But as we said on the script, remember there are seasons in terms of manufacturing in Lithium and we are getting into a period where, which is the winter part of the season. And we're going to have more rain and more snow and conditions, which are going to limit more, to some extent, our production of carbonate. So what we're expecting in the next 3 quarters is less carbonate available because of our manufacturing, like most people operating in this part of the world in the next couple of quarters. On the quantitative side, our costs continue to be good and our pricing will be positive. So it's a differential between all of these which create maybe a little bit or less of a novel performance in the remaining 3 quarters than we had in the first quarter. I don't know if you want to add anything in terms of this.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look historically at the earnings, the seasonality has been there. We're doing what we can to reduce volatility, but that seasonality is going to remain where the first and fourth quarter give us the most volume and flexibility on the mix w
componenttext: I think if you look historically at the earnings, the seasonality has been there. We're doing what we can to reduce volatility, but that seasonality is going to remain where the first and fourth quarter give us the most volume and flexibility on the mix we can sell.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as I think about some of the lithium carbonate that you're actually purchasing to convert to hydroxide, are you experiencing higher raw material cost for that or do you have lower prices locked in for the year and you're actually getting a margin
componenttext: And then as I think about some of the lithium carbonate that you're actually purchasing to convert to hydroxide, are you experiencing higher raw material cost for that or do you have lower prices locked in for the year and you're actually getting a margin benefit for some of that raw material you're purchasing?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first, as you know, most of the carbonate by a long shot we use is produced by us. So what we are buying under contract today versus the overall usage is incremental and what we are buying is lost under a long-term supply agreement. So we are not fac
componenttext: Yes, first, as you know, most of the carbonate by a long shot we use is produced by us. So what we are buying under contract today versus the overall usage is incremental and what we are buying is lost under a long-term supply agreement. So we are not facing significant price increases. In fact if it plays the way we expect it to play and once again, is going to have to be confirmed, but the way we look at it is for now, we are producing enough carbonates and buying enough to run our strategy around chloride, butyllithium, metal and hydroxide. And as time will go, we're going to have to sell more hydroxide. We're going to have to increase our capacity in hydroxide and we'll have to buy more of carbonate on the Exxon [ph] market, which should be at a time when our peer company will be increasing capacity and making the product more available in the market. So it looks like all of this is falling in place quite well. Sam, you want to add something?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. Pierre has it down well. The other thing will look at always is the incremental things we can do in Argentina. And there are small opportunities for small capital to increase our throughput in Argentina, which gives us some flexib
componenttext: Thanks for the question. Pierre has it down well. The other thing will look at always is the incremental things we can do in Argentina. And there are small opportunities for small capital to increase our throughput in Argentina, which gives us some flexibility as we go forward.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So right now, I would say there is no major issue around potential increase in the future of cost in terms of our ability to execute our strategy around carbonate and hydroxide.
componenttext: So right now, I would say there is no major issue around potential increase in the future of cost in terms of our ability to execute our strategy around carbonate and hydroxide.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Next, we'll go to the line of Mike Sison with KeyBanc.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pierre, when you think about -- you didn't change your outlook for crop protection markets this year. I understand, it's still difficult out there. But it does sound like you're feeling better about the integration and maybe the long-term potential. Can y
componenttext: Pierre, when you think about -- you didn't change your outlook for crop protection markets this year. I understand, it's still difficult out there. But it does sound like you're feeling better about the integration and maybe the long-term potential. Can you maybe map out where Ag Solutions income can go over time as hopefully things recover?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'll tell you the way we look at Ag Solutions right now. First, let me talk about the ag market as we see it for this year. I think we are not changing our view for 2016. We still believe it's a mid-to-high single digit downmarket, mostly d
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'll tell you the way we look at Ag Solutions right now. First, let me talk about the ag market as we see it for this year. I think we are not changing our view for 2016. We still believe it's a mid-to-high single digit downmarket, mostly driven by North America and Brazil in the high teens, and maybe Asia and Europe -- in the high single-digit, while Europe and Asia would be in the low to mid-single-digit decrease. So we are not changing our view. It could be maybe trending more toward the high single-digit overall global market. The way -- and why do I feel better about the way we are operating in the ag market? It is not because we are seeing a fundamental change in the market in the short-term. But what I think we are doing at FMC, I think the key difference is that we know better how to operate in this type of market. I can tell you, we see it on our number, we are not fighting to keep market share on sales of product. We are much more looking at 3 types of objectives. First, it's very important for us and focusing only on FMC project is to decrease FMC product in the channels. The second aspect is we want to be able by doing that to focus more on the quality of the sales, which is more term, price and collection. And then, looking at all of that, the objective is to align more sales with a normal demand pattern. You see that on the numbers in Q1 in North America. Sales down 35%, I think, on Slide 4, while product on the ground were up above market, 7%. So the way we are operating in the market today, I believe we have more control over our selling process than we might have had in the past when we got hit by the downturn. Beyond that, I would say -- I would not exclude the market to turnaround in 2017, but I have no indicators telling me that it will be the case. I think we are much more focused, Mike, on operating under the current conditions with very high control on term, price, managing very closely with -- in partnership with the customers, our inventory, to create much more predictability in our sales. So that's why the developed level of confidence for me is increasing at this stage. Market turnaround, I think we'll have to wait a little bit more to go into Q3, Q4 to have more visibility.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought you said at current level where the real is at, is it going to be negative this year or is it a positive? I just want to make sure I understand your commentary around foreign currency there.
componenttext: I thought you said at current level where the real is at, is it going to be negative this year or is it a positive? I just want to make sure I understand your commentary around foreign currency there.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You asked a million dollar question with the reais. The truth is the stability or the predictability of the movement of the real is really what matters. We talked about it in the past with regard to the timing of changes and the pace of changes. In Q1 and
componenttext: You asked a million dollar question with the reais. The truth is the stability or the predictability of the movement of the real is really what matters. We talked about it in the past with regard to the timing of changes and the pace of changes. In Q1 and Q2, just aren't periods in which we have a lot of commercial activity going on in Brazil. So it really is what it does in Q3. And again it isn't so much the level -- we've shown that in Q1 where with an average rate of 3.9 [ph] today is closer to 3.5 [ph] we were able to still capture pricing on a limited number of sales we have in Q1. The question will come in Q3, how stable, how predictable is the real? In the rest of the world when you look at the forward curve of the currency, it does not feel like a strengthening dollar is what the market is expecting. And so that, generally speaking, is what's factored into our numbers relative predictability, not a big strengthening of the dollar around the world. Q1 feels like when you look at where the dollar is today compared to a year ago, Q1 compared to the last of the quarters that we had those tough FX comps. So subject to any changes away from where the market expects today doesn't feel like currency will be quite the high-level that it was last year.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have really guided up your operating cash flow projections for the year at $50 [ph] million but raised your EBIT projections by about $10 million. Can you give us a sense where the big delta is coming in the operating cash flow? Is extremely increment
componenttext: You have really guided up your operating cash flow projections for the year at $50 [ph] million but raised your EBIT projections by about $10 million. Can you give us a sense where the big delta is coming in the operating cash flow? Is extremely incremental working capital?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a pretty straightforward story. We clearly have an increased expectation around EBITDA. But the truth is it's largely around working capital. And you have to bear in mind, if you look over the last few years, 2 years ago, we had a terrible perf
componenttext: Sure. It's a pretty straightforward story. We clearly have an increased expectation around EBITDA. But the truth is it's largely around working capital. And you have to bear in mind, if you look over the last few years, 2 years ago, we had a terrible performance with working capital with largely cash outflow. Last year, we turned out the corner and sort of stopped the bleeding and improved it a bit slightly. But this year, we expect that trend to continue so the working capital becomes a positive generator of cash flows. Our biggest focus is always going to be the Brazil receivables balance and getting that receivable balance down. We will also be very, very focused on inventory levels, our own inventory levels, and making sure we are very efficient and very thoughtful about what inventory we will, where we hold it, how much of it we hold. So it's coming in multiple different areas, but you should look at working capital the primary driver of increase in cash flow for 2016.

componenttext: I think you -- in the U.S. crop protection market, are you seeing any increase discounting or bundling by your competitors? And do you see any risk of perhaps maybe losing some shelf space in the retail channel from allowing your product inventories to be trimmed?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think whenever you talk about terms and pricing, we want to be highly cautious and solely comment about what we do. Our strategy today is quite simple. We are highly focused on maintaining our pricing at a healthy level. We are very vigilant in terms --
componenttext: I think whenever you talk about terms and pricing, we want to be highly cautious and solely comment about what we do. Our strategy today is quite simple. We are highly focused on maintaining our pricing at a healthy level. We are very vigilant in terms -- as you know, balance sheet is always a key challenge for a company like ours. And more than ever, we are highly disciplined on terms and not giving terms. What it means for us, and only talking for FMC, what it means for us is certainly, we are prepared to see timing change in ourselves. And that's what I've been talking about. We're not being willing to do anything to push product in the market if there is not a complete need for this product by the market. Specials is a word we use a lot. But when you have technical product to be sold, most production know they are needed and then you have commercial contract of customers. It is not a situation where because we are aligning ourselves with the market demand that we are taking an enormous risk to see somebody taking our shelf space by the end of the year and us not being able to sell our products. For example, Mark talked about our authority product line. It's a pre-emergent product. It's required needs to be bought in Q4 and Q1. We know this product will be sold. I think our strategy might be a big differentiator, but we are only focusing on ours along the line of what we discussed before.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Pierre, considering your comment about authority, would you say that the outlook for eventual penetration of the XTEND and the Enlist soybean products, does that -- is that a risk to your authority franchise in the Americas? Or could you see that as p
componenttext: And Pierre, considering your comment about authority, would you say that the outlook for eventual penetration of the XTEND and the Enlist soybean products, does that -- is that a risk to your authority franchise in the Americas? Or could you see that as potentially an opportunity where you might expand your franchise and move more over-the-top and bring in formulations with either 240 and ICAMPA.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steve, this is Mark. I've got a question earlier about how we thought it would be a headwind or tailwind. I think in the initial stages I expect rates to be reduced. Good news is we know it with Enlist and XTEND there would still be recommended use o
componenttext: Yes. Steve, this is Mark. I've got a question earlier about how we thought it would be a headwind or tailwind. I think in the initial stages I expect rates to be reduced. Good news is we know it with Enlist and XTEND there would still be recommended use of a pre-emergent herbicides of which authority is one of the market leaders. So we know we're going to have a substantial market there. I would say weed-resistant acres continue to grow, so we're going to see that pre-emergent continuing, certainly in the U.S. And as I said, earlier, in Argentina. I think from an over-the-top perspective, I mean, we have some very god products that we're going to be promoting, such as our cadet herbicide, which we think will be a great tank mix partner for those products and will offer a broader spectrum of control. Don't expect to see us into 4D and Dicamba. That's not the sort of business were going to be in. We're going to be in the more differentiated products, more highly specialized where we can bring value to the growers distribution.

componenttext: Pierre, the trend among food companies to reformulate to simplify is clearly getting faster. How much is that reformulation trend actually helping do you think? And do. You think about it as a tailwind?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the food market for us, there is an acceleration of -- the way we look at our markets in attrition and in health are interesting. In health, the good news is when the year with a customer, you're there for a while because are not being reformulate
componenttext: I think the food market for us, there is an acceleration of -- the way we look at our markets in attrition and in health are interesting. In health, the good news is when the year with a customer, you're there for a while because are not being reformulated out. The problem with that is it's not easy to gain new business. Well, the same applies to food but to the reverse. I think there is a trend to reformulate transformation. There's a very fast cycle, which gives opportunities for us. So the stronger we are with a product, the more opportunities. But by the same for new product and competitors. So I would say, today, it would be slightly a tailwind knowing that we are the largest market shareholder and more complete product line. But I don't see that as major change from the [indiscernible] do you have any commentary?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Eric, Mark. Eric Norris. We see this as a trend that has come and go in the industry. The industry is broad-based to Pierre's point. Unlike the health markets where there's very little change over periods of time, there's a great deal of change fr
componenttext: This is Eric, Mark. Eric Norris. We see this as a trend that has come and go in the industry. The industry is broad-based to Pierre's point. Unlike the health markets where there's very little change over periods of time, there's a great deal of change from every 2 or 3 years, whether it's low fat Atkins and now this simplification clean label phenomenon. It really does come down to the product line where we have, well-suited being all-natural based and then having the application capability to respond to them I nthe right places around the world, having spread of knowledge in the right places to the customers. So we're well-positioned for it. Anytime there's a reformulation, there's a challenge, right? So it does create in our part to respond. Going forward, we see the tailwind given the rest of our part when an application capabilities.

componenttext: Eric, in Pierre's comments you talked about product differentiation. Can you talk about how you think about product differentiation?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Specifically in the food market?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Sure. Yes.

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It all comes down understanding very well not only what's going on with your direct customer, the large food or small food company but consumers and being able to put together a formulation that meets the needs. So product differentiation for us is less a
componenttext: It all comes down understanding very well not only what's going on with your direct customer, the large food or small food company but consumers and being able to put together a formulation that meets the needs. So product differentiation for us is less about proprietary technology intellectual property patent that might drive more what happens in our ag business. More about the know-how be able to put some of the ingredients together that a specific need an understanding either color, texture or taste issues that might impact the success of that brand. So it really comes down to the differentiation around the application and the ingredients we bring as opposed to a proprietary ingredient in the food products itself.

componenttextpreview: Pierre, you are talking about can of the overall crop chemical market and the focus that FMC is going to have in terms of working inventory down and being disciplined around pricing in terms. I just want to get a clarification if others are competitors ar
componenttext: Pierre, you are talking about can of the overall crop chemical market and the focus that FMC is going to have in terms of working inventory down and being disciplined around pricing in terms. I just want to get a clarification if others are competitors are not acting rationally, pushing product in the market when the product is not needed as you were saying. FMC is not going to be participating in that kind of activity?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, I don't know what strategy our competitors are operating around market product discount and our rational, they intent to be. I think we made a decision and decision we made globally. We believe we are in a situation where the markets are such and
componenttext: Listen, I don't know what strategy our competitors are operating around market product discount and our rational, they intent to be. I think we made a decision and decision we made globally. We believe we are in a situation where the markets are such and the level of inventory in the channel are such, that you can't guide your activity by what the others are doing. I think we have is we're working very, very closely in cooperation with our customers who understand our strategy. I'm not going to sell in Q1 or Q2 or Q3 a product which is needed in Q4. And in exchange, we maintain a healthy pricing in current situation. And that's what we're going to be focusing. I believe what we're going to do this downturn. And here these turns around, we are not going to work hoping that the overall level of inventory in the market channel is going to go down. I think it's too tall of an order and too impractical. So we're going to be focused solely on FMC product. I think the number is quite spectacular. I think I said that many times, 34% sales down in the first quarter, North America plus 7% products on the ground, that is millions of dollars of inventory, which are outside of our customers inventory in which they will need to replenish when the market needs it. And that's the way we are operating. Our competitors will have to use the strategy which is appropriate for them.

componenttext: Okay. And then just focusing again on inventory. Obviously, in the quarter your inventories were significantly elevated due to the strategy that you're speaking of. Can you just talk about the timing that you expect to be able to work through that inventory along with what the channels going to be doing? And then ultimately, I think you said you expect improvements in the second half in North America, can you just talk a little bit about that?

headline: FMC Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way we look at it -- and there was a question before, I think it's Michael who asked that question, level of confidence in the market. I think our strategy today will allow us to have a more visibility in terms of the timing and level of our s
componenttext: I think the way we look at it -- and there was a question before, I think it's Michael who asked that question, level of confidence in the market. I think our strategy today will allow us to have a more visibility in terms of the timing and level of our sales because we become less dependent upon what the market is doing and rushing to place sales to be safe and have those on the shelves. So what it does to us, it creates more predictability and increase the level of confidence of how the quarters ahead of us are going to be unfolding. We know, I mean, we know, which product will be required, usually which technology will be required depending upon the season in Q4 and Q1 and Q2. And that's a discussion we have with our customers and that's the way we're operating right now. So it's giving us a bit more certainty on how things will unfold.
