headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now turn the conference over to Brian Angeli, Vice Presiden
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now turn the conference over to Brian Angeli, Vice President of Investor Relations for FMC Corporation. Mr. Angeli, you may begin.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to FMC Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today is Pierre Brondeau, President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Paul Graves, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Pier
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to FMC Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today is Pierre Brondeau, President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Paul Graves, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Pierre will begin the call with a review of FMC second quarter performance and discuss the outlook for Q3 and the full year 2016. Paul will provide an overview of select financial results. The slide presentation that accompanies our results, along with our earnings release and 2016 outlook statements, are currently available on our website and the prepared remarks from today's discussion will be made available at the conclusion of the call.
As with our prior calls, Mark Douglas, President, FMC Agricultural Solutions; Eric Norris, President FMC Health and Nutrition; and Tom Schneberger, Vice President and Global Business Director, FMC Lithium, will join to address questions.
Before we begin, let me remind you that today's discussion will include forward-looking statements that are subject to various risks and uncertainties concerning specific factors, including but not limited to, those factors and they divide in our earnings release and then our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Information presented represents our best judgment based on today's information. Actual results may vary based on these risks and uncertainties.
Today's discussion will focus on adjusted earnings for all income statement and EPS references and pro forma revenue and segment earnings for FMC Agricultural Solutions. A reconciliation and definition of these terms, as well as other non-GAAP financial terms to which we may refer during today's conference call, are provided on our website.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Pierre.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. As you can see on the first slide, for the second quarter of 2016, FMC reported revenue of $810 million and adjusted operating profit of $143 million. Adjusted EPS of $0.69 was $0.01 below the second quarter o
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. As you can see on the first slide, for the second quarter of 2016, FMC reported revenue of $810 million and adjusted operating profit of $143 million. Adjusted EPS of $0.69 was $0.01 below the second quarter of 2015, but above the mid-point of our guidance range. 
Ag Solutions delivered another solid quarter and it continues to realize the benefits of the Cheminova acquisition. Lithium outperformed on higher sales volumes and higher realized prices across the portfolio with lower operating cost from ongoing Manufacturing Excellence program.
Earnings in Health and Nutrition were below expectations as results in omega-3 were significantly weaker than anticipated. Based on our performance to date and the outlook for the back half of the year, we are increasing full year adjusted EPS guidance by $0.05 to $2.60 to $2.90 per share. I will provide more detail on how that breaks down across each of the businesses shortly. But first, I will discuss second quarter results for each of our 3 segments, starting with Ag Solutions on Slide 2.
Overall, market conditions and our performance in the quarter were in line with our prior expectations. We remained focus on reducing the level of FMC product inventory in the channel and on maintaining discipline on price and terms. We also took actions needed to complete the product rationalization that began in late 2014. 
For the second quarter, Ag Solutions reported revenue of $515 million and segment earnings of $101 million, slightly ahead of the mid-point of our guidance range. Revenue declined 19% compared to the second quarter of 2015, largely due to lower sales volume, unfavorable weather conditions in Europe and Asia, the drawdown of channel inventory by customers in most regions and planned product rationalization all contributed to the decline in volume in the quarter.
Excluding planned product rationalization, revenue declined broadly in line with the crop protection market as a whole. Segment earnings declined 14% compared to 2015, as the impact of lower sales volumes, less favorable product mix in Asia and North America and the stronger U.S. dollar were partially offset by lower operating cost. Compared to pro forma results from Q2 last year, operating margin increased 100 basis points, reflecting pricing discipline, the elimination of sales of low-margin products due to portfolio rationalization and cost savings from the Cheminova integration.
As we move to Slide 3, I will first need a few comments on the global crop protection market, then I will move to review FMC's performance by region and discuss the outlook for Q3 and the full year. So first, the market.
Overall, conditions in the global crop protection market were as expected and it will change from Q1. In North America, soft commodity prices continue to put pressure on some incomes resulting in more cautious bang behavior by growers and elevated inventory levels across the channel. 
In Europe, unfavorable weather conditions early in the quarter, most notably in Central and Western Europe, reduced market demand, leading to lower volumes and increased channel inventory in certain countries. In Brazil, channel inventory across the market remained elevated, especially for insecticide. And while foreign exchange rate have been more stable, growers continue to be negatively impacted by a lack of credit availability.
In Asia, weather conditions were poor across most of the region resulting in weaker market demand. We believe these challenging market conditions will persist for the remainder of the year and we still forecast that the global crop protection chemical market will decline by mid to high single-digit percent in 2016 on a U.S. dollar basis. I will now discuss FMC's performance in light of these market conditions.
First, let me address the lower-than-expected revenue for the quarter. Market in Asia and Europe were weaker than expected, but the main driver of the lower revenue is a more successful and aggressive product rationalization. 
We continue to manage the quality of our sales in order to protect margins, earnings and working capital. In North America, our strategy remained one of the standing price and terms, allowing the level of FMC product inventory in the sales channel to reduce. Although we see point of view that inventory of FMC products in the channel is declining. Reflecting the benefits of the actions we took early in the season to reduce inventory of FMC product in the channel, sales in Q2 increased 5%. We saw strong demand for FMC's authority brand of pre-emergent soybean herbicide and independent data show that the authority brand has taken market share this year. We also saw grower support for the extended fungicide products we can now offer as a result of the Cheminova acquisition.
In Europe, revenue declined by 19%, driven largely by poor weather conditions and reduced volume due to the planned product rationalization, as well as the impact of transitioning to a direct market access model. However, the product rationalization and move to direct market access have resulted in improved operating margins in the region.
In Latin America, revenue declined 43%, primarily as a result of steps we took to reduce the level of FMC product inventory in the South channel in Brazil. We were great by our ability to recover U.S. dollar pricing in the quarter. While not matching to overall segment performance, given the seasonally lower sales volume, realized price increased in Brazil more than offset the negative impact of FX on a reported revenue.
In Asia, the combination of poor weather condition, further portfolio rationalization and the stronger U.S. dollar caused revenue to decline 22% compared to the second quarter last year. Moving on to the outlook for Ag Solutions. 
Our full year segment earnings guidance remains unchanged at $380 million to $420 million. For the third quarter, we expect segment earnings of between $80 million and $90 million. At the mid-point of guidance, second half segment earnings will increase by approximately 35% compared to 2015, driven by improved performance in Brazil and Latin America and additional cost savings from the Cheminova integration. The steps we have already taken to rationalize our product portfolio and reduce the level of FMC inventory in the channel, in the sales channel, leave us well-positioned as we enter the 2016, 2017 crop season in the Americas.
The relative stability of the Brazilian real over the past few months gives us increased confidence in our ability to recapture price despite tightening credit condition from growers and weak market demand as channel inventory levels decline. We expect full year segment earnings margin to be between 17% and 18%, which at the mid-point, represents more than 250 basis points of improvement compared to 2015 driven by more favorable mix, improved pricing in Brazil and realization of cost savings. We remain on track to deliver the incremental cost savings target of $60 million to $70 million in 2016 and the full run rate cost saving of $140 million to $160 million by the middle of next year.
Moving on to Health and Nutrition on Slide 4. The business reported second quarter segment revenue of $195 million and segment earnings of $45 million. Revenue declined approximately 6% and earnings declined approximately 11% compared to the second quarter of 2015. 
Results for the quarter were negatively impacted by worse-than-expected performance of omega-3. The headwinds we saw in omega-3 over the past year increased in the second quarter. Specifically, prices and volumes were much lower than anticipated. There is significant overcapacity in the industry, which, combined with lower demand for higher products, acceptance even greater pressure on prices than we saw earlier in the year. 
We have seen new entrants with business at prices that are close to cash cost of production, resulting in considerably lower volume for our products in several key area. We have aggressively taken costs out of this business with 6 cost falling by almost 40%. We continue to pursue new opportunities for high-end cost alteration products, but do not expect to recover these lost volumes this year and do not anticipate the change in pricing levels any time soon.
Excluding omega-3, results were in line with expectations. In nutritional ingredients, volumes in the quarter were slightly below Q2 2015, largely due to timing as orders shifted to the second half of the year. In health excipients, sales volumes increased in all key pharmaceutical market.
Given performance to date in omega-3 and our expectations for the rest of the year, we are lowering our guidance for Health and Nutrition. We now expect full year segment earnings to be in the range of $190 million to $196 million, roughly flat with 2015, and third quarter segment earnings to be in the range of $44 million to $48 million. We continue to expect operating margins of approximately 25% for the full year. helped by lower operating cost and improved production yields.
Turning next to retail on Slide 5.  Lithium delivered another outstanding quarter. Revenue increased 15% year-over-year to $63 million and segment earnings more than tripled to $16.5 million. Lithium's performance reflect a success of FMC strategy of constructing lithium carbonate into higher value downstream specialty product supported by strong pressure performance especially in Argentina in our hydroxide facility.
Higher sales volume, higher average prices in all major product categories, improved mix and lower operating costs, all contributed to deliver segment earnings above the top end of our prior guidance range and push segment earnings margin to over 26% in the quarter.
We expect supply/demand conditions to remain tight for the remainder of the year as previously announced capacity expansions across industry have been slow to come online. This reinforces our confidence in favorable pricing conditions to the remainder of 2016. 
For the full year, we expect segment earnings to be in the range of $58 million to $66 million, an increase at the mid-point of approximately 30% compared to prior guidance and nearly 3x segment earnings in 2015. Higher prices and lower operating costs compared to last year will support operating margins in the range of 24% to 25% for the year.
We expect third quarter segment earnings to be in the range of $13 million to $17 million as the benefit of higher prices will be partially offset by seasonally lower production at our operations in Argentina. FMC's Lithium business is positioned to deliver significant earnings growth in 2016 and beyond. In May, we announced plans to triple our production capacity of lithium hydroxide to 30,000 metric tons by 2019 in order to meet growing demand from our customers starting with a 4,000 metric ton expansion scheduled to come online in 2017.
Last week, we announced we will accelerate that capacity expansion and we now expect 8,000 metric tons to come online by the middle of 2017. We continue to evaluate the turning or further capacity expansion and expect the entire 20,000 metric ton of additional capacity to be online by 2017. We believe we will more than double the revenue and earnings of our Lithium business between 2016 and 2020, resulting in over 20% per year growth through the rest of this decade.
We recognize that our hydroxide investment plans require us to have cost-effective access to sufficient lithium carbonate. Our current carbonate capacity is sufficient to support the expansion in FMC's hydroxide production to at least 2018. 
Beyond this, we are actively pursuing multiple task to ensure we are not carbonate constrained. First, we have several low options to debottleneck our Argentina operations, potentially adding 20% capacity. Second, we are in ongoing discussions with multiple carbonate producers. We have announced plans to add capacity in the coming years and are exploring mutually beneficial long-term supply agreement or trouble partnerships. And of course, we retained the option to add significant capacity at our operation, our existing operation in Argentina beyond the debottlenecking I just mentioned. Consequently, we are highly confident that access to lithium carbonate will not be a constrain in our ability to extend our hydroxide business in the coming years.
Before I turn the call over to Paul, I will comment briefly on the outlook for the third quarter and full year 2016 on Slide 6. As I mentioned, we are maintaining full year segment earnings for Ag Solutions and adjusting our full year earnings expectation for both Health and Nutrition and lithium. As a result, on a consolidated basis, we are increasing full year adjusted EPS guidance by $0.05 at the mid-point to $2.60 to $2.90 per share. For the third quarter, we expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $0.53 to $0.63. I will now turn the call over to Paul to discuss select financial results.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pierre. As usual, I'll start with the income statement and specifically, the tax rate. Our adjusted effective tax rate for the full year is now expected to be in the range of 24% to 25%, giving us a small benefit this quarter compared to Q2 las
componenttext:
Thank you, Pierre. As usual, I'll start with the income statement and specifically, the tax rate. Our adjusted effective tax rate for the full year is now expected to be in the range of 24% to 25%, giving us a small benefit this quarter compared to Q2 last year.
This lowered late is largely due to the continued change in the mix of our earnings away from high tax jurisdictions, such as the U.S, towards regions were tax rates are lower. Foreign exchange was not a major factor in our results this quarter with the stronger dollar mainly impacting the Ag Solutions segment. 
Various Asian currencies,  plus the Mexican peso, was due the drivers of the FX headwinds in the quarter. The second quarter is not a period of significant activity in Brazil. And therefore, the recent strengthening of the year are have a limited impact in our financials in the quarter. However, with an FX rate in the quarter that was weaker than the same period of last year and with the price list that largely reflective of current spot rate, the combined effect of price and currency in Brazil was a net positive to our second quarter earnings.
Looking into the second half of the year. The recent stability in the real U.S. dollar exchange rate means that the assumptions regarding the future exchange rate that has underpinned our guidance is unchanged. To remind you, our guidance has assumed that we have a real to U.S. the dollar rate that is relatively stable with no major short-term swings in the FX rate, combined with a price list that largely reflects the prevailing spots exchange rate. 
Sitting here today, both of those assumptions remain unchanged. And therefore, we do not expect is very positive or negative impact on our second half performance from the real-FX rate compared to our previous guidance provided these conditions hold.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow on Slide 7. We continue to make progress in increasing our cash generation while maintaining discipline on capital spending. For the first half of the year, our adjusted cash from operations was 40% higher than the first half of last year, driven primarily by stronger working capital performance. 
We remain on target to meet our outlook for the full year of $450 million to $550 million of adjusted cash from operations. Net debt fell by $90 million compared to the first quarter and by over $120 million since the start of the year. 
The second quarter is important period for us in terms of cash collections in Brazil. We remain very focused on the credit capacity of our customers, particularly given the constrained access to third-party financing for Brazilian growers. This has an impact on both our ability to collect cash from customers and our willingness to continue to extend credit in the form of new sales. 
On the first point, we were pleased with our performance in collecting in Brazil, with net cash collections slightly ahead of our expectations and particularly good progress in collecting from our past due balances. As a result, we saw meaningful reduction in our Brazil receivables balance. However, it is still significantly higher than we would like and we will remain focused on reducing our exposure in the coming quarters.
The credit tightness in Brazil has been an important factor for us for several quarters now, but our willingness to extend credit to certain segments of the market reduced. As we head into the key second half selling season in Brazil, our guidance reflects the disciplined approach to credit exposure. 
And with that, I will turn the call back to Pierre.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. And before I continue with my remarks, let me correct a statement I made. The 20,000 ton of additional lithium hydroxide capacity is to be online by 2019, not as I say 2017.So to continue and to conclude. I am very pleased with the over
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. And before I continue with my remarks, let me correct a statement I made. The 20,000 ton of additional lithium hydroxide capacity is to be online by 2019, not as I say 2017.
So to continue and to conclude. I am very pleased with the overall execution of our strategy and improved outlook for the year. Despite ongoing challenges facing the agricultural industry, our strategy and the actions we have taken in the back half of 2015 and the first half of 2016 give us strong confidence in the performance for the remainder of the year. 
We have remained focused on reducing the level of FMC product inventory in the channel, maintain discipline on price and term, aggressively manage our mix by rationalizing our product line leading to stronger margins. This strategy, combined with a successful integration of Cheminova and the more benign FX situation, have increased the predictability of our business and will drive the second half performance of Ag Solutions with earnings up 35% compared to pro forma results for 2015.
We are investing in our technology roadmap in order to offer unique value-added solutions to our customers. We see higher acceptance rates for our new products launches, including our theological platform, and remain on track to introduce our new active ingredients pipeline starting in 2017.
Lithium continues to deliver strong performance altering its product mix and increasing output to meet growing market demand. FMC's focused strategy has enabled the business to take advantage of favorable market conditions to rely significant earnings growth in 2016. Our announced capacity expansion strengthens FMC's leadership position in lithium hydroxide and specialty lithium application and will deliver further growth in the years to come.
Health and Nutrition had a weaker-than-expected quarter. However, the business continues to generate high margins and return and demand across key nutritional and pharmaceutical market will support growth over the second half of the year.
Finally, we are generating increased operating cash flow to improve our balance sheet. We are on track to increase adjusted cash from operations by approximately 40% in 2016. 
I thank you for your attention this morning. And with that, I will turn the call back to the operator for questions.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Can you just comment a little more on your longer-term expectations for your European business, given your shifts or I'd say rather evolution of your good market strategy? And then also, parse out your views for Northwest here versus CIS. And then also, you mentioned product rationalization as well. Just any additional detail would be helpful.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Mark. Well, first of all, for Europe. Obviously, we now have a very different business model with the acquisition of Cheminova. I think you're going to expect just to see, over the long haul, outperformance in the marketplace. And it kind o
componenttext: Chris, this is Mark. Well, first of all, for Europe. Obviously, we now have a very different business model with the acquisition of Cheminova. I think you're going to expect just to see, over the long haul, outperformance in the marketplace. And it kind of fits with your second question around the CIS in Western Europe. We obviously had a bigger exposure in Western Europe with the Cheminova acquisition, but we see a lot of opportunity in the CIS countries, other parts of Eastern Europe in terms of Poland and Hungary, Czech, Slovakia, as well as the Ukraine. Introduction of new technologies is important for us in Europe. The portfolio is strong. But without pipeline, we have new products that will benefit both niche crops and especially cereals, where Cheminova have exposure that FMC did not have. So if you think of outperformance versus the market, it's really going to be cereals and the niche crops, especially in the South, and then accelerated growth in these.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then just a quick follow-up. Just can you just comment a little bit more about the working capital for me you saw there in the quarter. And then also on a go-forward basis. Specifically, how do you typically evaluate growth versus credit risk
componenttext: Perfect. And then just a quick follow-up. Just can you just comment a little bit more about the working capital for me you saw there in the quarter. And then also on a go-forward basis. Specifically, how do you typically evaluate growth versus credit risk as we head into the third quarter with Brazil? And is it becoming more dependent on crop types, farm size or even region within Brazil? Just any comments on the puts and takes will be helpful.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, let me touch on that. The working capital progress we made really, if you look at the cash flow improvement we had over last year in the first half of the year, you can put almost all of that into embedded collections in Brazil. So we made significa
componenttext: Sure, let me touch on that. The working capital progress we made really, if you look at the cash flow improvement we had over last year in the first half of the year, you can put almost all of that into embedded collections in Brazil. So we made significant progress over there. We've talked many times about the steps we're taking a company to any one thing that's changed that, it's about getting some momentum behind those collection conversations. Now in terms of growth versus credit. Actually, we really think about it that way. We think about that in terms of credit. We think about the ability of the customer to repairs, the stability of the customer and their access to finance.  There are all natural differences by crop and by region in Brazil. And we obviously, factual that in the way that we go-to-market. But we have the same questions that we ask and the same standards that we set regardless of region or crop, essentially, based on our competence that we will recover the payments from our customers on the terms that we sell them to. That's the single largest factor that we consider.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I would add, Chris, you know Brazil very well. Given where the exposure is, I would say the North, the Toronto regions are where it is probably the most stressed. The South with the pull ups and the distribution is in better shape, and
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I would add, Chris, you know Brazil very well. Given where the exposure is, I would say the North, the Toronto regions are where it is probably the most stressed. The South with the pull ups and the distribution is in better shape, and then sugarcane as well. Sugar industries come through challenges. But with the price of sugar today, they are in better shape as they go forward into 2017. But it's definitely the North where the stress is.

componenttext: Thank you. No, we can't and we don't want to comment on competitors. It's sometimes quite difficult to understand the overall inventory in the chalice. There is product in the channel but really to comment specifically about our competitors, that would not make sense for us to do so.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, and I think this -- the comment I would make are valid for the entire second half. We are getting now into a position. If you look compared to the backhand of 2015, where there is no of improvement. First of all, our product mix is getting
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, and I think this -- the comment I would make are valid for the entire second half. We are getting now into a position. If you look compared to the backhand of 2015, where there is no of improvement. First of all, our product mix is getting much stronger than what it was. We -- our actions to work with from low margin third-party more generic products is working very well. So we are increasing the margins of our products through mix. Second of all, we have been pretty successful over the last 3 or 4 quarters in moving our price. So we're and looking at the importance of Brazil and Latin America in Q3 and Q4 and taking into account the pricing versus FX situation, we are in a stronger position. So blend of stronger volume full we're going to see in the second half of the year, a better mix because we are moving away from third-party products and the pricing FX situation will lead to, first of all, to more predictable business. We have a much better visibility going in the second half of the year than we had in a long time and with stronger margins for the business.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mike Harrison with Seaport Global securities.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pierre, you mentioned last call that Q2 were in the Lithium business was when you were expecting some seasonal production weakness there, yet you were able to deliver well ahead of your guidance. Can you talk about what drove that upside during the quarte
componenttext: Pierre, you mentioned last call that Q2 were in the Lithium business was when you were expecting some seasonal production weakness there, yet you were able to deliver well ahead of your guidance. Can you talk about what drove that upside during the quarter and whether there can be some potential upside as we look at your guidance for Q3 and Q4?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. I think the seasonal weakness is not only in Q2. It's in the back end of Q2 through Q3. So we've seen part of it and we're going to keep on seeing it. It's usually due to the fact that it is winter. There is more rainy season right now in Argen
componenttext: Certainly. I think the seasonal weakness is not only in Q2. It's in the back end of Q2 through Q3. So we've seen part of it and we're going to keep on seeing it. It's usually due to the fact that it is winter. There is more rainy season right now in Argentina where we're operating. So it's not only a Q2 phenomenon, it's a back of Q2, early Q3. I think the visibility we have today due to our production is quite, quite correct that the earnings level. Mainly, there is multiple reasons, which have been leading the improve of earnings. First of all, the mix. We are moving more business to all of lithium hydroxide, where we've been able to operate our plants quite, quite well and where there is a healthy demand and pricing situation. Second of all, our plants have been operating also very well for carbonate production and we have been -- and we are continuing to do that for the second half, selling more product made within the company than third-party product we would resell. And then there is some volume. So if I look at the second half of the year, I think our earnings is quite in line with our expectation. I don't think there is a light of upside. Most likely what you will see is we decided not to change the revenue range because we are a little bit below the middle point of the range initially. Looking to demand for back half of the year, it's most likely to lead us to where they higher range from a revenue standpoint. But I believe we have forecasted in lithium for Q3, Q4 are correct, unless, less, I'd say the only place where I could see upside but it is not possible for us to predict that today is pricing. Pricing is always something, depending upon demand, and how capacity, come on stream. So that one, we've made some assumption, you never know.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a question just on the product rationalization that you did in Ag Solutions. Is that mostly legacy FMC products or are there some Cheminova products? And is there any more to come? Just trying to get a sense of whether we could see some additiona
componenttext: And then a question just on the product rationalization that you did in Ag Solutions. Is that mostly legacy FMC products or are there some Cheminova products? And is there any more to come? Just trying to get a sense of whether we could see some additional pressure there. And at some point, do you hit a point where you see some negative leverage as a result of scaling back on the number of products you're selling?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the product rationalization is very well advanced today. I think it's a mix. It's as much from Cheminova legacy products than it is from FMC products. Both company used to resale third-party product as a service to customers. And that seems you ca
componenttext: I think the product rationalization is very well advanced today. I think it's a mix. It's as much from Cheminova legacy products than it is from FMC products. Both company used to resale third-party product as a service to customers. And that seems you can afford to do it at a given time with a very healthy market, you cannot do in the market is more intense. So it was a normal thing for us to move away. We had very precisely defined what those product could be. I'm very pleased with the speed at which the organization responded to that. I think more than half of the shortfall in our sales today in the second quarter is coming from product rationalization, but that's pretty much where it is. So you will not see numbers going beyond what we've talked about, which was total run rate, adding this year of $350 million, which is $100 million more than we did last year, we did $250 million last year. And this is it. There will be no further as far as we can see actions to be taken.

componenttext: It's pretty good. Let's -- why don't we just put it in perspective. The global public health market is about $700 million, and that's within the total Ag space crop protection chemicals of over $51 billion. So really, for mosquito control, the market worldwide is about $325 million to $340 million and the U.S. is about $90 million of that. So you can get a sense of the scale of that business. In particular applications, we have a very good market share. But only with our [indiscernible] but with a product called malathion that we bought from Cheminova. So just keep it in perspective. Then if you want to talk about it a lot, but the U.S. market is only $90 million out of that $700 million.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wish I could predict FX markets that well, Frank. I mean, I wouldn't be in this job. I'm pretty confident around that. I think the key is that we see a more predictable. You see the peso has been a surprising area for us. We didn't -- I mean, we never s
componenttext: I wish I could predict FX markets that well, Frank. I mean, I wouldn't be in this job. I'm pretty confident around that. I think the key is that we see a more predictable. You see the peso has been a surprising area for us. We didn't -- I mean, we never see him coming. And the Brazil has been -- the real has been some kind of a bright spot, not because of the absolute rate, but as I mentioned about the stability around the rate. And I think that's sort of the keepers as we look forward, that's the ability of the rates and a lack of surprise is more important to us on most of our business than the actual movement in the exchange rates.

componenttext: What kind of visibility do you have in Health and Nutrition in the second half of this year? Your guidance seems to imply an acceleration and profits, which seems seasonally maybe a little bit different than the past few years. So given sort of the comments that you called out about omega-3, can you just walk us through some of the key drivers for the second half?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. I think we do have pretty good visibility on our 3 segments today from a demand standpoint. But it is important to understand that the earnings growth, especially in the fourth quarter, is maybe more predictable because it is June  to a cost si
componenttext: Certainly. I think we do have pretty good visibility on our 3 segments today from a demand standpoint. But it is important to understand that the earnings growth, especially in the fourth quarter, is maybe more predictable because it is June  to a cost situation. We always work our cost and decrease of cost. But the way costs flows into operations depend upon the speak that we should turn your product. And I think we call that capitalized variance. But the main reason for the bump in earnings in the backhand of the year is due to the fact that we will be operating at a lower cost than moving operating via the quarters in previous year. That is why you will see such a turn. So it is not due to a major turn in demand for any of our products, but it's much more the benefit of prior activity we've done on operational costs and manufacturing excellence.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then of this $60 million to $70 million of full year cost synergies from Cheminova, can you quantify how much of that you realized in this first half? And then maybe just holistically, beyond just cost synergies, where do you see
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then of this $60 million to $70 million of full year cost synergies from Cheminova, can you quantify how much of that you realized in this first half? And then maybe just holistically, beyond just cost synergies, where do you see the integration process for Cheminova today?

componenttext: Yes, thanks. I think at a run rate basis, we want to close the past here on our rate basis in the $30 million to $40 million range for the first half of the year on the Cheminova.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Talk a little bit about the integration side. From an integration perspective, we are very much done on the commercial side, that's all in place. A lot of the functional groups are also fully integrated and operating. We have some systems that we're still
componenttext: Talk a little bit about the integration side. From an integration perspective, we are very much done on the commercial side, that's all in place. A lot of the functional groups are also fully integrated and operating. We have some systems that we're still working through as a Dean in Europe, as an example, which will be completed early in the fourth quarter. And then the long lead time item is how we bring together the different manufacturing units, the total manufacturing units and the formulating units. We are well progressed with that. We still have some to go, but that will occur over time. And the basic need there is to make sure we have registrations as we move products around the world. So that's the right limited set, but everything of this pretty much done right now.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think from a Cheminova integration, we're going to start reporting. I mean, we'll answer any questions you guys might have. But we can almost declare success. Everything is in place to reach, as we discussed by the middle of next year, the $140 million
componenttext: I think from a Cheminova integration, we're going to start reporting. I mean, we'll answer any questions you guys might have. But we can almost declare success. Everything is in place to reach, as we discussed by the middle of next year, the $140 million to $160 million run rate, the 800  to 900  positions being eliminated. So we are very much more than on track ahead of initial schedule. And I think lots of the remaining activities are more under impulse shop around IT, SAP, science integration. So much more back-office integration than anything during the front end of the business.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk about the expected lithium capacity, lithium carbonate capacity increase in 2017 based on what you see in here in the marketplace. Is that coming on stream, a lot of it in the first half of 2017 and therefore, would have a
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk about the expected lithium capacity, lithium carbonate capacity increase in 2017 based on what you see in here in the marketplace. Is that coming on stream, a lot of it in the first half of 2017 and therefore, would have a negative impact on pricing?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rosemarie. Yes, we're starting to see some exchange of volumes coming on even in the back half of 2016, mostly out of the new exciting capacity that's coming online in Australia. As you know, there's also some capacity in Chile, and it there ha
componenttext: Thank you, Rosemarie. Yes, we're starting to see some exchange of volumes coming on even in the back half of 2016, mostly out of the new exciting capacity that's coming online in Australia. As you know, there's also some capacity in Chile, and it there has been capacity ramping up in Argentina targeting back end of 2016 and early 2017. So these were the volumes that we're watching. And I characterize it, could be anywhere between 50,000 to 75,000 tons by early 2017. So as Eric comment earlier, this is where we make pricing assumption, and we're monitoring the conditions as we interact with customers in terms of pricing expectations.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that particular capacity addition is going to be smaller than the demand increase, is in it? And therefore pricing is going to come down across the Board including lithium hydroxide or you don't think so?
componenttext: And that particular capacity addition is going to be smaller than the demand increase, is in it? And therefore pricing is going to come down across the Board including lithium hydroxide or you don't think so?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, first, yes, there will be -- we are expecting, as time goes, starting in '17 and into '18, we're expecting carbonate pricing to grew more toward normal pricing, which mean a lower pricing we are currently seeing when they will be more or they balance
componenttext: No, first, yes, there will be -- we are expecting, as time goes, starting in '17 and into '18, we're expecting carbonate pricing to grew more toward normal pricing, which mean a lower pricing we are currently seeing when they will be more or they balance between in the carbonate demand and the supply. It will not impact the hydroxide pricing. If you look right now and if you put together all of the hydroxide capacity increase, which actually we are leading, they are very much in line with the demand increase. So from a pricing standpoint, we my night see hydroxide rising tremendously the year to come. But I think one of want to be in a healthy pricing situation for the next 3 to 4 years.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add a little bit to that, Rosemarie. In our hydroxide business, we're targeting specific sequence of that demand, where high quality hydroxide, where they're willing to pay for the quality we bring to the markets. So when we look at supply/dem
componenttext: And just to add a little bit to that, Rosemarie. In our hydroxide business, we're targeting specific sequence of that demand, where high quality hydroxide, where they're willing to pay for the quality we bring to the markets. So when we look at supply/demand, we're looking even specifically at that customer mix versus one that might trade-off to carbonate or other supply.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my second question. Also inventory, overall inventory in the Ag sector. You said that you have loyalty FMC product inventories. But without talking about any specific competitors, what do you see in terms of the overall inventory channel? Is it declin
componenttext: And my second question. Also inventory, overall inventory in the Ag sector. You said that you have loyalty FMC product inventories. But without talking about any specific competitors, what do you see in terms of the overall inventory channel? Is it declining? Or is it still growing? Or more or less sort of flat -- has it plateaued?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think from a -- as I said, I want to repeat, we're mostly focusing on our inventory. But overall, if I would have or if we would have an overall statement, we believe overall inventory in the channel is declining. We do not believe right now we are at a
componenttext: I think from a -- as I said, I want to repeat, we're mostly focusing on our inventory. But overall, if I would have or if we would have an overall statement, we believe overall inventory in the channel is declining. We do not believe right now we are at a turning point from a market standpoint. But we can see we are at a place where the dialogue with the customers is changing. There is more certainty. There's more productivity. Still means that the inventory in the channel is pretty heavy. We are not yet at a situation where it's not -- but the dialogue is changing. And I believe -- really [indiscernible] to decrease their inventory. We believe we most likely aggressive. But overall, I think the situation is improving.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question comes from line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. Paul, you talked about the longer timeline for rationalization of the manufacturing in Europe. Is that sort of a 2020 time goal in your mind? Or is there a specific target in your mind? And then second question to Latin America again. As we th
componenttext: Two things. Paul, you talked about the longer timeline for rationalization of the manufacturing in Europe. Is that sort of a 2020 time goal in your mind? Or is there a specific target in your mind? And then second question to Latin America again. As we think about the working capital cycles in cotton and sugarcane, is your penetration in that market permanently shifting your working capital cycle in a material way? My understanding is Cheminova manage working capital much differently than you did using more receivables, for example. And I'm curious whether that has all shifted over to your way of doing things.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me address first the question on the manufacturing rationalization. Right now, we are at a place where we have a stable manufacturing network for Ag business. We are always looking at improving. But any improvement, any decisions today is always
componenttext: Well, let me address first the question on the manufacturing rationalization. Right now, we are at a place where we have a stable manufacturing network for Ag business. We are always looking at improving. But any improvement, any decisions today is always a mid-to long-term decisions because there is some product registrations, which are changing when you do a change of manufacturing. So I have to say that right now, as any company would do, we are keeping our options open. But we are in what I would call a stable manufacturing network. And we will see as time goes what are the best decisions to be taken for our business in terms of network. But today, we're not penalized by the structure we have and it's a matter of doing continuous improvement and being able to supply what will be requests of the market at a time when the market turns around.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're comfortable then not being quite as asset light as you have been sort of in the medium term?
componenttext: So you're comfortable then not being quite as asset light as you have been sort of in the medium term?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are asset light. I think if you think about FMC prior to the acquisition of Cheminova, our manufacturing cost was 95% asset light. I would say today, maybe we're at 90%. We should not believe that the fact that we have a plant in India in panel income
componenttext: We are asset light. I think if you think about FMC prior to the acquisition of Cheminova, our manufacturing cost was 95% asset light. I would say today, maybe we're at 90%. We should not believe that the fact that we have a plant in India in panel income and a plant they have in London are fundamentally changing the mix of product we shall made until manufacturers versus what is being made today. Those are big plans. But you know in the big scheme of things, the production capacity versus what we do with total network is fairly small. So it is our fundamental departure to what we used to be in the past.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Working capital question down there in Brazil. Sugarcane and cotton can have very, very different terms, part tends to be longer-term sugarcane tend to be short term although that's very depending on the nature of the planting cycles and on the financial
componenttext: Working capital question down there in Brazil. Sugarcane and cotton can have very, very different terms, part tends to be longer-term sugarcane tend to be short term although that's very depending on the nature of the planting cycles and on the financial health of the sugarcane guidance. But as a rule, as we shifted away from cotton, would we expect to see our working capital terms common and to what sugarcane also does the same thing. I would not though expect that you go to TrackBack to our working capital balance as you look at it. It's definitely fact that helps but it's not so much that you're going to see a major movement in our numbers. In terms of how Cheminova approach it. Cheminova, this is segment to a different difference. Cheminova did not have a different approach to working capital than anybody else in the industry. They did have a different approach to heavily finance that working capital. And to be blunt, as a weak balance sheet company with very unsophisticated treasury operations, they used to be some very, very expensive local financing a result, which can you the present are there to reducing the working capital. And with appropriate for non-U.S. GAAP reported, it was appropriate for some investment grade company, it was incredibly expensive and we'll recently factor in why their overall profitability was so low and it's not something we intend to do.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of Aleksey Yefrenov with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Aleksey Yefrenov with Nomura Securities.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is the current competitive environment in Latin America and North America? Do you see your competitors generally be more disappointed up our production prices?
componenttext: What is the current competitive environment in Latin America and North America? Do you see your competitors generally be more disappointed up our production prices?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not going to talk about what competition is doing on price. Tell you where we are. As Pierre said earlier, we're doing everything we can to make sure we manage price in terms across North America. And secondly, in Brazil while we have reduced
componenttext: Well, we're not going to talk about what competition is doing on price. Tell you where we are. As Pierre said earlier, we're doing everything we can to make sure we manage price in terms across North America. And secondly, in Brazil while we have reduced our exposure to the Brazil market by taking out through product rationalization, significant amount of volume and revenue. But we're very focused on making sure that we maximize price, not only terms of pricing, sort of across the portfolio on what we're selling. I think you're going to see all sorts of different activities as we go through the next year. But for us, it's very much around protecting the margins, protecting the value of the business and certainly, looking after working capital.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in term of pricing, just to get back to one of the comment Paul made around the balance of FX and pricing. As you know, we tend to have a rule in Brazil where we index price on currency. Last year, we were with a pricing running after the currency
componenttext: I think in term of pricing, just to get back to one of the comment Paul made around the balance of FX and pricing. As you know, we tend to have a rule in Brazil where we index price on currency. Last year, we were with a pricing running after the currency and trying to move up our price. This year, the same process of adjusting pricing to currency is going the other way, which mean it is not any longer us asking the customer to take higher price, but the customer asking us to lower the price more toward the currency. So needless to say that for all of us, regardless of what behavior, individual companies would take, it is a major conversation from the profitability of the pricing. And this FX situation give us a much better position to talk about pricing, more control in term of understanding pricing in the next 2 quarters. And I think it's got to apply to every company. It is just an FX price situation.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And turning to Europe and crop protection. You had some revenue declines there. How much of that was your move to direct market? And was it a one-time impact or is there any way to improve that next year?
componenttext: And turning to Europe and crop protection. You had some revenue declines there. How much of that was your move to direct market? And was it a one-time impact or is there any way to improve that next year?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the direct market situation is a one-time impact. It is just a capital of situation, which happened all the time when you do this kind of a transfer. First of all, you work with your distribution network, which are moving away from. Those guys have i
componenttext: Yes, the direct market situation is a one-time impact. It is just a capital of situation, which happened all the time when you do this kind of a transfer. First of all, you work with your distribution network, which are moving away from. Those guys have inventory. They have start -- they are feeling it when you're replenishing your own now where to sell. So there is still a time where you have 2 networks, which have to roll up for a little while. And you have to give the time to your distributors to sell the product they weren't supposed to sell the product by contract. Second of all, you are [indiscernible] so where your distributors are not replenishing their inventory in advance. So by the time we get into -- this is happening at the transition now. I believe by the time we get into European season Q1, Q2 next year, we should be in a very normalized situation and it will be stable for the future.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of Mike Sison with KeyBanc.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Mike Sison with KeyBanc.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious. You maintained your outlook for crop protection markets this year down mid to high single-digit. What was it down in the first half? And just trying to gauge what the expectation is for the second half in terms of demand.
componenttext: Just curious. You maintained your outlook for crop protection markets this year down mid to high single-digit. What was it down in the first half? And just trying to gauge what the expectation is for the second half in terms of demand.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think in the first half, the way I would look at it, Mike, is when we gave the range, we said mid single-digit to high single-digit. Maybe we were thinking about more toward when we started this process, the lower end of the range, maybe 5%, 6%, 7%.
componenttext: So I think in the first half, the way I would look at it, Mike, is when we gave the range, we said mid single-digit to high single-digit. Maybe we were thinking about more toward when we started this process, the lower end of the range, maybe 5%, 6%, 7%. We are more today on a 7%, 8% more toward the higher end of the range. And that is due, maybe less due to channel inventory than it was to specific reasons in Asia and Europe, mostly driven by weather. So for us, when we look at the market, if you remember, we were thinking about North America and Latin America in the higher end of the range, and this being helped by flattish to slightly down market in Europe and Asia. We don't see that any longer. I mean, we still see North America and Latin America on the higher end of the range, but we see Asia and Europe being down in the 5%, 6% for this year. That is why today, we are looking at maybe more the higher end of our range. For us, what we've been doing is we've been able, no matter what, to protect our earnings by being even more drastic on pricing, more drastic on product rationalization. So we'll be slightly lower on sales. But we believe we are going to be -- we're going to have very solid performance in the second half and productivity on the earning side.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then so the fourth quarter for Ag Solutions, you talked about better visibility than in the past. But just curious, what sort of gets you to the high end of the range? I mean, it's pretty wide in terms of the top end, given your guidance for Ag
componenttext: Okay. And then so the fourth quarter for Ag Solutions, you talked about better visibility than in the past. But just curious, what sort of gets you to the high end of the range? I mean, it's pretty wide in terms of the top end, given your guidance for Ag Solutions from the third quarter and the low end. What sort of gets you to the top?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say always the same answer. When we give the middle of the range, it under normal circumstances from a demand and weather standpoint. And those -- there is always a range. You just need, you just very strong insect pressure or other pressure. And
componenttext: I would say always the same answer. When we give the middle of the range, it under normal circumstances from a demand and weather standpoint. And those -- there is always a range. You just need, you just very strong insect pressure or other pressure. And you drive that either to the lower or either to the [indiscernible]. Today, we believe we are very comfortable with the middle of the range to see anything going up or down would be due to external events not linked to channel inventory or anything that kind, but much more to specific agricultural seasonal situation, mostly weather.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Peter Butler with Glen Hill Investment.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Peter Butler with Glen Hill Investment.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pierre, early on regarding lithium, you folks had a conservative outlook on shorter-term of lithium growth, but you saw good possibilities longer-term. I knew this outlook has been proven correct. What do you see now for the longer-term growth of lithium?
componenttext: Pierre, early on regarding lithium, you folks had a conservative outlook on shorter-term of lithium growth, but you saw good possibilities longer-term. I knew this outlook has been proven correct. What do you see now for the longer-term growth of lithium? And how do you -- how does your research pipeline on lithium derivatives look compared to what you're seeing from competitors and how does this change your future position on earnings and cash flow growth, et cetera?

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter. Yes, so lithium, I have to say, we do have increased confidence in the future. Today, we believe this market is getting more and more solid. I have to say that we are prudent. But the big breakthrough for us is technology, we're able to
componenttext: Thank you, Peter. Yes, so lithium, I have to say, we do have increased confidence in the future. Today, we believe this market is getting more and more solid. I have to say that we are prudent. But the big breakthrough for us is technology, we're able to develop from a manufacturing standpoint allowing us to add very low capital spend and division cost of operations, ability to create 4,000 to 8,000 tons mutuals for lithium hydroxide instead of having to build in one shot, a 20,000 or 30,000 tons. So today, we have an improved view and more certain view of what lithium hydroxide is doing. But on the work we've done in the last 2 years was to develop a manufacturing process allowing us to follow the demand growth. Which means that if the growth is not as we're expecting, we can stop 1 or 2 of these modules manufacturing and slowdown the capacity increase we have planned. If the demand becomes more aggressive, very easy for us to speed up the building of those modules. So first, your question, yes, we have increased confidence. Our strategy we're highly focused on the downstream product, where we have the highest profitability. Third, we have a safety net around demand by these manufacturing process we have in place allowing to match the demand. Where are we on our forecast? We are taking a much middle of the range. We are far in the process and but its ability for the numbers I gave to you to take the highest prediction from AV companies. So that could be upside, but you know, we are prepared also for the downside. And maybe I'll ask Tom to comment on the technology.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and thanks for the question. On the technology, we've got a technology roadmap. And I'd say that with the strategy that we've been undertaken on the high-value products, the biggest shift is the increased collaboration and formalized collaboration wi
componenttext: Yes, and thanks for the question. On the technology, we've got a technology roadmap. And I'd say that with the strategy that we've been undertaken on the high-value products, the biggest shift is the increased collaboration and formalized collaboration with our customers. So we do have a number of exciting opportunities that are being discussed with customers and being trialed with customers, and we're looking forward to that. It will continue to add to high-quality sales of new lithium derivatives and new applications with existing lithium derivatives.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as it was the last question, let me close with a couple of words before I hand the closing comments to Brian. I think we went through those 2 quarters very highly focused on delivering what we promised to do. Everything we've done in the 2 quarters hav
componenttext: So as it was the last question, let me close with a couple of words before I hand the closing comments to Brian. I think we went through those 2 quarters very highly focused on delivering what we promised to do. Everything we've done in the 2 quarters have done a few things for us. First of all, I believe from an Ag standpoint, even if the market are not yet returning to the level of growth this kind of market could expect to see one day, we have improved highly controlled visibility and productivity of our own business. I think from a lithium standpoint, it is a bright spot for us. We have refined our strategy. And I have to say the breakthrough we had in technology about lithium hydroxide manufacturing are already enormous win for us looking for the future. Our penetration, the business is solid. The business is highly profitable. But we also understand the challenges we have on omega-3 and its something we'll be focusing on in the quarters to come. So with this, I'm going to turn the call back to Brian.

headline: FMC Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Thank you, Pierre. As always, appreciate the time and the questions. I'll be available for the call to address any further questions that you may have. So with that, thank you and have a good day.
